Temperature: Temperature decreases as the level of greenhouse effect decreases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Atmospheric CO2 decrease is the forcer in this scenario.  CO2 decrease results in a lower level of the greenhouse effect.
Volcano: Volcanoes, Mountains, and Isolation are not affected by a change in CO2. They are likely not to change over the 10 MY time scale of this simulation.
Ice: Lower temperatures will cause ice to accumulate, but response time is longer than 200 years
Weathering C Burial: Lower temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which decreases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Lowering weathering rates decrease carbonate deposition, but response times are long (~100,000 years)
Sediment: Decreasing precipitation transports and deposits less sediment, but carbon burial response times are long

Temperature: Temperature decreases as the level of greenhouse effect decreases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Atmospheric CO2 decrease is the forcer in this scenario.  CO2 decrease results in a lower level of the greenhouse effect.
Volcano: Volcanoes, Mountains, and Isolation are not affected by a change in CO2. They are likely not to change over the 10 MY time scale of this simulation.
Ice: Decreasing temperatures will cause ice to accumulate, but response time shorter than this time scale.
Sea: Decreasing temperature and accumulation of glacial ice lowers sea level in this time scale.  Decreased volcanic activity also decreases sea level, but it is constant in this scenario.
Weathering C Burial: Lowering temperature decreases evaporation and precipitation, which decreases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Lowering weathering rates decreases carbonate deposition, but response times are ~100,000 years
Sediment: Although C burial due to sediments and release of C due to weathering probably change, they are likely to be minor.

Temperature: Temperature decreases as the level of greenhouse effect decreases.  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: Atmospheric CO2 decrease is the forcer in this scenario.  CO2 decrease results in a lower level of the greenhouse effect.
Ice: Lowering temperatures will cause ice to accumulate, but response time shorter than this time scale.
Sea: Decreasing temperature and accumulating glacial ice lowers sea level in this time scale.  Volcanic activity also changes sea level, but it is constant in this scenario.
Weathering C Burial: Lowering temperature lowers evaporation and precipitation, which decreases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Lowering weathering rates decreases carbonate deposition;  response times are ~100,000 years

Temperature: Temperature increases as the level of greenhouse effect increases  Temperature quickly responds to changes in atmospheric CO2 level.
CO2: CO2 rises because sinks have dropped way off (in this case carbonate deposition is the sink that changed).
Ice: Rising temperatures will melt ice, but response time shorter than this time scale.
Sea: Rising temperature and Melting glacial ice raises sea level in this time scale.  Volcanic activity also raise sea level, but it is constant in this scenario.
Weathering C Burial: Rising temperature raises evaporation and precipitation, which increases weathering rates.
CO3 Desposition: Rising weathering rates increase carbonate deposition;  response times are ~100,000 years
